node.text: We got an exclusive look at a big upgrade to Snapchat’s camera called Scan. Like a visual search engine, it scans what you’re looking at to identify things like breeds of dogs, similar clothes, plants, and AR effects to try.

node.title: Exclusive: Snapchat’s biggest camera upgrade in years

node.text: The Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 3 foldable phone turns into an Android tablet that is actually nice to use. An objectively ridiculous selfie camera is offset by stylus support, water resistance, and an improved screen that is way nicer to the touch. Dieter Bohn has all that and more in this review.

node.title: Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 3 review: nearly normal

node.text: Samsung’s new $150 Galaxy Buds 2 are the latest addition to their wireless earbud lineup that also includes the Galaxy Buds Pro and the Galaxy Buds Live. The Buds 2 have active noise cancellation and are 15% smaller and 20% lighter than their predecessor, the Galaxy Buds+. In a growing market with great wireless earbuds like the Sony WF-1000XM4 and Apple Airpod Pros, do the Bud 2’s new features and smaller design bring enough value to rival its competition? @becca.farsace  has the full review (and mic test) to find out.

node.text: Rumors of its demise have been greatly exaggerated and the Pixel 5A is here with a bigger 6.34-inch screen, IP67 waterproof rating, and a larger 4680mAh battery. And at $449, it’s also less expensive than the 4A 5G. There’s still no wireless charging or a fast refresh rate screen, but the 5A adds up to more than the sum of its specs. Is this The Year of the Pixel Flagship or will the a-series still rule supreme?

node.title: Google Pixel 5A review: bigger battery, lower price

node.text: Today we’re getting our first look at the fruits of Samsung’s smartwatch collaboration with Google: the new Galaxy Watch 4 and Galaxy Watch 4 Classic. It’s a big deal in wearables, because after years of trying to go it alone with its own Tizen platform on smartwatches, Samsung is finally biting the bullet and collaborating with Google on its operating system.

node.title: Galaxy Watch 4 and Galaxy Watch 4 Classic hands-on

node.text: Samsung’s new Galaxy Z Fold 3 and Galaxy Z Flip 3 are the company’s most refined foldable phones yet. The Fold 3 supports the S Pen stylus on its large display, and the Flip 3 has a much more useful cover screen. Samsung says both phones are also more durable, thanks to design upgrades, and they’re now officially rated IPX8 for water resistance.

node.title: Galaxy Z Fold 3 and Z Flip 3 hands-on

node.text: Don't call it a Steam Machine: this is the Steam Deck, a 7-inch handheld gaming PC from gaming software giant Valve. We flew to Valve's HQ in Bellevue, Washington to spend about an hour with the machine and compare it to Nintendo's Switch and other portable systems.

node.title: Valve Steam Deck hands-on: a Switch-like portable gaming PC

node.text: The Nothing Ear 1s are $99 wireless earbuds with active noise cancellation. They are the first product from OnePlus co-founder Carl Pei’s Nothing tech startup — and where their design excels, their function falls flat.

node.text: We got some hands-on time with the Google Pixel 6 and Pixel 6 Pro. Each has Google's new, custom-designed system on a chip, called Tensor. The long and the short of it is simple: Google's actually trying to make a real flagship phone this year. Will it be enough?

node.text: More than 10,000 collisions between animals and airplanes are reported each year to the FAA, and those numbers are on the rise. Specialists work around the clock to keep airport wildlife strikes from turning deadly, employing a range of tactics from habitat management to sequencing bird DNA. Can they keep up with the pace of travel? The Verge Science team ventured from the tarmac to the feather identification lab to find out. Check out our latest video to learn more — and find out what “snarge” is.

node.title: Your airplane hits a bird. Now what?

node.text: Satellite data shows that cities have hotter average surface temperatures than surrounding areas. Pollution, asphalt, and lack of green spaces all contribute to what scientists call the "urban heat island effect." This extreme heat can have deadly consequences. The Verge science team hit New York’s streets with a thermal camera to learn just how hot cities can get, and why.

node.title: We took the temperature of New York’s hottest neighborhoods

node.text: iOS 15 and iPadOS 15 are Apple’s latest and greatest operating systems, and the public beta gives a first look at new features like SharePlay, Focus modes, improved iPad multitasking, and more.

node.title: iOS 15 preview: the good, the bad, and the weird

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Verge on August 30, 2021.

node.text: The new $150 OnePlus Buds Pro are the company’s most refined set of true wireless earbuds so far, with active noise cancellation, wireless charging, and a lightweight design. Photo by: @chriswelch

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Verge on August 29, 2021.

node.text: There’s finally a new Densha de Go! train controller, and it’s awesome. It's �the first new console controller for Taito’s train-driving series Densha de Go! in 14 years. Zuiki has released a model designed to work with Densha de Go! Hashirou Yamanote-sen for the Nintendo Switch. Photos by: @345triangle

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Verge on August 29, 2021.
Photo by The Verge on August 29, 2021.
Photo by The Verge on August 28, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, controller and text that says 'EQ S MODE SELECT +VOLUME CHAT ロ 111 Ù Y X B A TURTLE RECON'.

node.text: The $60 Recon controller from Turtle Beach does far more than your average controller. It can boost any set of wired 3.5mm headphones with premium headset features, and you can customize its controls for more precision. Photo by: @cam.faulkner

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Verge on August 27, 2021. May be an image of phone and screen.

node.text: The Samsung Galaxy A42 5G is a thoroughly decent midrange phone that doesn’t really need to exist. It features a big 6.6-inch screen, generous 5,000mAh battery, and 5G support that includes the faster mmWave variety. �It’s fairly priced at $400 but �mmWave is still scarce and highly range-limited. Photo by: @allisonjo1

node.text: We got an exclusive look at a big upgrade to Snapchat’s camera called Scan. Like a visual search engine, it scans what you’re looking at to identify things like breeds of dogs, similar clothes, plants, and AR effects to try.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Verge on August 25, 2021. May be an image of saddle-stitched leather and text that says 'SONY'.

node.text: Sony’s new flagship soundbar, the HT-A7000, delivers phenomenal audio quality. It also has two HDMI 2.1 inputs that can pass through 4K gaming at 120Hz from an Xbox Series X or PlayStation 5. It's a �$1,300 soundbar that does pretty much everything. Photo by: �@chriswelch

node.text: The Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 3 foldable phone turns into an Android tablet that is actually nice to use. An objectively ridiculous selfie camera is offset by stylus support, water resistance, and an improved screen that is way nicer to the touch. Dieter Bohn has all that and more in this review.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Verge on August 23, 2021.

node.text: The Zephyr Pro is a new version of a “sweat-proof” gaming mouse that came out last year. The built-in fan is quieter and more powerful. But is it just a gimmick? Follow the link in our bio for the full review. Photo by: @345triangle

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Verge on August 22, 2021. May be an image of screen.

node.text: Acer’s Nitro XV282K KV is the company’s new $900 gaming monitor, with two HDMI 2.1 ports, that supports 4K resolution and 120Hz refresh rates. If you can afford it, it’s a great monitor to use for PS5 and Xbox Series X games. Photo by: Jay Peters

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Verge on August 21, 2021. May be an image of laptop, screen and outdoors.

node.text: Lenovo’s ThinkPad X1 Yoga Gen 6 is the latest convertible in the company’s premium ThinkPad X-Series line. It’s an excellent product with a 16:10 matte touchscreen, but it doesn’t offer a ton that you can’t get for much cheaper in Lenovo’s consumer devices like the Yoga 9i. Photo by: @monicawchin

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Verge on August 20, 2021. May be an image of sandals.

node.text: HTC’s $1,300 Vive Focus 3 is an enterprise-focused standalone VR headset with premium hardware but an intentionally near-nonexistent consumer app ecosystem. �The Focus 3, which is meant for businesses, research institutions, and other professional settings. At $1,300, it costs more than four times as much as the Quest 2’s $299 base price. If you want a device for playing video games, exercising, or using most VR social spaces, don’t buy HTC’s standalone headset. Photo by: @thedextriarchy

node.text: Samsung’s new $150 Galaxy Buds 2 are the latest addition to their wireless earbud lineup that also includes the Galaxy Buds Pro and the Galaxy Buds Live. The Buds 2 have active noise cancellation and are 15% smaller and 20% lighter than their predecessor, the Galaxy Buds+. In a growing market with great wireless earbuds like the Sony WF-1000XM4 and Apple Airpod Pros, do the Bud 2’s new features and smaller design bring enough value to rival its competition? @becca.farsace  has the full review (and mic test) to find out.
